â
'''Google, Inc''' {{nasdaq|GOOG}}, is a [[United States|U.S.]] public corporation, initially established as a privately-held corporation in [[1998]], that designed and managed the Internet [[Google search]] engine. Google's corporate headquarters is at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]] and employs over 4,000 workers. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Dr. Eric Schmidt]], former [[CEO]] of [[Novell]], was named the Chief Executive Officer when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down. The company's overview web page states "Google's mission is to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful." The company has especially stayed in the news since September even more than before surrounding both major announcements and controversies.
+
'''Google, Inc''' {{nasdaq|GOOG}}, is a [[United States|U.S.]] public corporation, initially established as a privately-held corporation in [[1998]], that designed and managed the Internet [[Google search]] engine. Google's corporate headquarters is at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]] and employs over 4,000 workers. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Dr. Eric Schmidt]], former [[CEO]] of [[Novell]], was named the Chief Executive Officer when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down. The company's overview web page states "Google's mission is to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful." Google has especially stayed in the news since September even more than before surrounding both major announcements and controversies.
==History==
==History==
===Beginnings===
===Beginnings===
Line 100: Line 100:
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{Web reference | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | URL=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | date=June 1 | year=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price. On [[June 7]], 2005, Google was valued at nearly $52 billion, making it one of the world's biggest media company by stock market value.
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{Web reference | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | URL=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | date=June 1 | year=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price. On [[June 7]], 2005, Google was valued at nearly $52 billion, making it one of the world's biggest media company by stock market value.
â   â
In the Summer of 2005, Google announced that it had purchased a 767 jumbo jet.
 
With Google's increased size comes more competition from large mainstream technology companies. One such example is the rivalry between Microsoft and Google [http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,1706872,00.asp]. The two companies are increasingly offering overlapping services, such as webmail ([[Gmail]] vs. [[Hotmail]]), search (both online and local desktop searching), and other applications (for example, Microsoft's [[Virtual Earth]] competes with [[Google Earth]]). Some have even suggested that in addition to an [[Internet Explorer]] replacement Google is designing its own Linux based [[operating system]] called Google OS to directly compete with [[Microsoft Windows]]. Rumors of a google browser are fueled by the fact that Google is the owner of the [[domain name]] "gbrowser.com". This corporate feud is most directly expressed in hiring offers and defections. Many Microsoft employees who worked on Internet Explorer have left to work for Google. Microsoft has been touting its [[MSN Search]] engine to counter Google's competitive position. This feud boiled over into the courts when Kai-Fu Lee, a former vice-president of Microsoft, quit Microsoft to work for Google. Microsoft sued to stop his move by citing Lee's non-compete contract (he had access to much sensitive information regarding Microsoft's plans in China). [http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=internetNews&storyID=2005-09-02T215817Z_01_MCC278865_RTRIDST_0_NET-MICROSOFT-GOOGLE-DC.XML] The case is still in the courts.
With Google's increased size comes more competition from large mainstream technology companies. One such example is the rivalry between Microsoft and Google [http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,1706872,00.asp]. The two companies are increasingly offering overlapping services, such as webmail ([[Gmail]] vs. [[Hotmail]]), search (both online and local desktop searching), and other applications (for example, Microsoft's [[Virtual Earth]] competes with [[Google Earth]]). Some have even suggested that in addition to an [[Internet Explorer]] replacement Google is designing its own Linux based [[operating system]] called Google OS to directly compete with [[Microsoft Windows]]. Rumors of a google browser are fueled by the fact that Google is the owner of the [[domain name]] "gbrowser.com". This corporate feud is most directly expressed in hiring offers and defections. Many Microsoft employees who worked on Internet Explorer have left to work for Google. Microsoft has been touting its [[MSN Search]] engine to counter Google's competitive position. This feud boiled over into the courts when Kai-Fu Lee, a former vice-president of Microsoft, quit Microsoft to work for Google. Microsoft sued to stop his move by citing Lee's non-compete contract (he had access to much sensitive information regarding Microsoft's plans in China). [http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=internetNews&storyID=2005-09-02T215817Z_01_MCC278865_RTRIDST_0_NET-MICROSOFT-GOOGLE-DC.XML] The case is still in the courts.
Line 202: Line 200:
* September 2005
* September 2005
â   â
* September 22: Google leases over 270,000 sq. feet in NYC telecom hotel.
 
* September 28: both Google and [[Ames Research Center]] disclosed details to a long-term research partnership. In addition to pooling engineering talent, Google plans to build a 1-million square foot facility on the ARC campus.[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2005/05_50AR.html]
* September 28: both Google and [[Ames Research Center]] disclosed details to a long-term research partnership. In addition to pooling engineering talent, Google plans to build a 1-million square foot facility on the ARC campus.[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2005/05_50AR.html]
â
* September 2005: Google makes offer to San Francisco city goverment to offer [[WiFi]] Internet access to [[San Francisco]]. 12 other companies apply for license. ([http://wifi.google.com/download.html Google Secure Access])
+
* September 2005: Google moves into offering free [[WiFi]] Internet access to [[San Francisco]] ([http://wifi.google.com/download.html Google Secure Access])
*October 2005: Google and [[Sun Microsystems]] join forces to offer online word processing and spreadsheet functions. The partnership will help promote Sun's [[OpenOffice]], [[Solaris Operating Environment|Solaris OS]] and [[Java platform]]; which in turn will assist Google to compete with Microsoft's current dominance in the [[Microsoft Office|Office]] and [[Operating System]] software areas.
*October 2005: Google and [[Sun Microsystems]] join forces to offer online word processing and spreadsheet functions. The partnership will help promote Sun's [[OpenOffice]], [[Solaris Operating Environment|Solaris OS]] and [[Java platform]]; which in turn will assist Google to compete with Microsoft's current dominance in the [[Microsoft Office|Office]] and [[Operating System]] software areas.
Line 213: Line 209:
* October 7 2005: Google creates [[Google Reader]], an online RSS reader.
* October 7 2005: Google creates [[Google Reader]], an online RSS reader.
â
* October 9, 2005: Google CEO says that it will take 300 years to digitize and organize all of the world's information. He made these same comments in June.
  â   â
* October/November 2005: [[Google Wallet]], an online payment system similar to [[PayPal]], is rumoured to be released soon
  â

Line 308: Line 301:
*'''Talk''': Allows users with Gmail accounts to communicate with each other through instant messaging and have online conversations.
*'''Talk''': Allows users with Gmail accounts to communicate with each other through instant messaging and have online conversations.
*'''Videos''': Allows the user to limit a search to videos on the internet; Use Google to find reviews and showtimes for movies playing near you.
*'''Videos''': Allows the user to limit a search to videos on the internet; Use Google to find reviews and showtimes for movies playing near you.
â
*'''Blogs''': Blog Search allows the user to search blogs and RSS feeds. Results can be sorted by relevance or by date. Although it allows you to search specific blogs, this feature is currently malfunctioning.
+
*'''Blogs''': Blog Search allows the user to only search blogs. Results can be sorted by relevance or by date. Although it allows you to search specific blogs, this feature is currently malfunctioning.
â
*'''Scholar''': Allows users to search some peer-reviewed, scholarly [[Scientific_journal|journals]]
+
*'''Scholar''': Allows users to search peer-reviewed, scholarly [[Scientific_journal|journals]]
Clicking on the "More" tab at the top directs the user to even more Google Services such as [[Blogger]], University Searches, Google products in their Labs section, Help and Alerts.
Clicking on the "More" tab at the top directs the user to even more Google Services such as [[Blogger]], University Searches, Google products in their Labs section, Help and Alerts.
